5000233~Honey-Cinnamon Ice Cream~3192~330~317~24~204~1308~689~The first time my parents came to Rialto
column2: site of my first pastry chef gig
column3: my mom laughed out loud when she saw the dessert menu. Every dessert featured ice cream
column4: and one dessert had two. My dad and I are both complete ice creamaholics
column5: and once I was in a position to make my own ice creams
column6: they showed up everywhere I could put them! I made fruit ice creams
column7: nut ice creams
column8: spiced ice creams. You name the ingredient and I made it into an ice cream. This was one of my favorites. Originally it was a honey-vanilla ice cream
column9: but this variation popped up one day when my vanilla supplier missed a shipment. Needing to make a quick ice cream base for that evening's service and stuck without vanilla beans
column10: I turned to the spice larder
column11: selected a few cinnamon sticks
column12: and a new flavor was born. I like the way the warm cinnamon flavor melds with the natural earthiness and roundness of the honey. An added plus is that honey is a sweetener that lends itself to extra-creamy ice creams
column13: which you'll notice immediately when you taste this one after churning.

column1: 5005687~Brown Rice Pilaf with Saffron and Ginger~935~175~6~21~21~841~0~Healers have touted saffron's medicinal properties since the days of Hippocrates

Its scarcity (it takes some four thousand crocus blossoms to create an ounce of saffron) and the belief that it could be used to treat everything from wounds to the plague even caused the Austrians to go to war over the spice during the Dark Ages. This is at least one feudal folk myth that modern science has corroborated. Studies have shown that saffron has outstanding antibacterial and antiviral properties and also aids digestion. People sometimes balk at saffron's cost

5001684~Baked Breaded Cauliflower~1561~70~22~67~112~2865~430~If there's a way to bake a vegetable

column7: and bake it? Note: To save time
column8: I nuke the cauliflower
column9: adding no additional liquid. The drops of water clinging to the head after it's washed are quite enough. I simply put the cauliflower in a 2 1/2-quart microwave-safe casserole deep enough to accommodate it
column10: one with a tight-fitting domed lid. I then center the covered casserole in my microwave oven
column11: set the cook-time at 14 minutes
column12: and hit HIGH (full power). My microwave oven is a 650-watter; newer models of higher wattage will do the job faster—perhaps twice as fast. But you will know your particular model's prowess better than I. If you choose to steam the cauliflower instead
column13: allow 8 to 10 minutes in a covered saucepan over moderate heat or until crisp-tender—there should be about 3/4 inch of water in the pan. No steamer rack needed. While the cauliflower cooks
column14: ready the sauce and bread crumb topping. That way no time wasted. Tip: For mellower flavor and smoother sauce
column15: substitute freshly grated Parmigiano Reggiano cheese for the Cheddar our mothers and grandmothers would have used.

column1: 5002219~Francis Butler's Texas Tamale-Stuffed Turkey~680~85~24~21~22~1714~54~"Francis Butler grew up on the family ranch and continues to preside over the dry
column2: windy land. The lonesomeness of ranch life
column3: she says
column4: was offset by ""group cooks"" such as the annual Thanksgiving tamale making: ""Wild turkey hunting has been a West Texas sport for as long as anybody remembers
column5: and tamale-stuffed turkey may have been an early tip of the hat to the Mexican ranch hands who've been around for at least as long as the turkey. This recipe dates back to the early 1900s. I got it from a family whose grandmother was German but had been raised in Mexico. I make it most often in the cold months
column6: but I've been known to put a tamale-stuffed turkey in the roasting pit in my time
column7: as well. You can use commercial tamales
column8: of course
column9: but I like the two-day ritual of making tamales and then making the turkey. I always double or triple the tamales and freeze the extra. These days people use more barnyard turkey than they do wild. Before you go thinking that's a sorry thing
column10: let me tell you this. You feed your chickens or turkey some chile peppers before you decide. That spicy sweet flavor gets into the meat and you know what they mean when they say it doesn't get any better."""

5005032~Rugelach~2021~301~148~73~91~1820~135~"Sometime during the first year of my marriage
column2: I visited my mother-in-law in her kitchen. There she was
column3: listening to the radio
column4: whistling (she is a formidable whistler) and rolling cream cheese dough around raisins and nuts to form the crescent-shaped cookies known as rugelach. I was spellbound—I'd had no idea that rugelach could be made at home. As far as I knew
column5: rugelach
column6: like ketchup or ships-in-bottles
column7: were only made in laboratories. But here was my mother-in-law shaping the cookies with ease. And a short time later
column8: there I was
column9: eating them with ease. These cookies weren't like the rugelach my mother bought every week at the local German bakery—they were much better. I was so excited I asked for the recipe.

column1: My mother-in-law wrote it out in her precise hand on a 3-x-5 index card. And
column2: as she wrote
column3: she told me that this recipe was not exactly the same as the one her mother used
column4: that it had come from Mrs. Strauss
column5: her next-door neighbor
column6: and that she was sure I'd have no problem making the cookies as long as I didn't overmix the dough.

column1: She was right. I was a newcomer to the world of baking
column2: but I had no problem with the dough
column3: the only potentially tricky part of the process.

column1: Since then
column2: I've made rugelach countless times
column3: but nowadays my dough is even more foolproof because I make it in a food processor. I've also made a few other changes to the recipe. While my mother-in-law's rugelach were filled with cinnamon-sugared nuts
column4: mine also include a slick of jam
column5: some currants and a handful of chopped chocolate. This is a very old recipe
column6: and I have no doubt that everyone who has made it has added or subtracted a little bit to make it her own—and my mom-in-law
column7: Mrs. Strauss
column8: and I expect you to do the same."

column1: 5002693~Maple-Glazed Tuna with Pear-Potato Salad~785~83~77~0~55~357~0~"I met twelve-year-old Frank Liranzo when I was teaching a kids' cooking class at the YMCA's environmental camp in Huguenot

column3: a process I'd read about but never seen in action. Frank was one of the campers
column4: and he got to experience firsthand the old art of making maple syrup. ""You put tubes into the trees so the sap flows out
column5: he says. ""When it first comes out of the tree
column6: it tastes like sugary water. Then we went to the sugar shack where we saw the sap boiled down until it tasted like syrup."" At the camp
column7: I made this Maple-Glazed Tuna with Pear-Potato Salad for the kids. ""I thought it would taste really sugary
column8: but it didn't
column9: Frank told me. ""First I tasted the fish
column10: then a hint of mustard
column11: and then an aftertaste of the maple syrup."" I love how the syrup adds sweetness and a beautiful caramelized crust to the meaty tuna steaks
column12: while the sweetness of the pears in the accompanying potato salad balances nicely with the glazed tuna."

column1: 5014409~How To Temper Chocolate~3180~408~317~45~181~1362~136~Tempered chocolate has a shiny
column2: flawless appearance. It feels firm and breaks off with a snap when you bite into it and it melts smoothly in your mouth
column3: allowing you to fully enjoy the flavor. Slowly heating and cooling melted chocolate while stirring puts it into temper. If chocolate is not tempered properly
column4: the cocoa butter crystallization is uncontrolled and uneven
column5: which results in an unattractive chocolate that is dull or has white streaks running through it. Untempered chocolate may feel rough or tacky and have a cakey
column6: almost chewy texture. And it is more susceptible to heat and humidity
column7: melting more easily and spoiling more quickly. Some simple candy recipes do not require tempered chocolate. However
column8: candies such as truffles
column9: dipped chocolates
column10: and chocolate bars require tempering to achieve their signature appearance
column11: taste

Making toum requires a slow and steady hand to emulsify the garlic and oil in the food processor; consider toum like an aïoli with no egg. There are many methods cooks use to avoid a broken toum emulsion

column6: Chef Payard told me. He sandwiched a mound of rum-scented almond cream between two large squares of homemade puff pastry and then quickly scalloped the edges of the pastry to look like a sunflower. Slash-slash-slash went his paring knife over the top pastry as he etched sun rays into the surface. The whole thing went into the oven and emerged golden brown with a glorious starburst pattern on top. It put every other pastry I had ever made previously to shame."

5017506~Norma Naranjo's Tamales~4552~543~7~189~199~6902~444~Highway 84 runs from Santa Fe to Colorado. About forty minutes north of Santa Fe

column5: outposts of national grocery chains

column8: Hutch and Norma Naranjo's sprawling midcentury home is set about fifty years back from the road
column9: a shrine to the tug-of-war between new ways and traditional ones. In the backyward Mr. Naranjo built two hornos (behive-shaped adobe ovens). Inside the house
column10: a handmade wreath of dried chiles hangs on one wall and a string of made-for-tourists ceramic peppers on another. A naïve painting of St. Francis hangs not far from a cluster of the dream catchers that the couple and their two grown children fashion from string
column11: feathers
column12: and yarn
column13: just as their Pueblo ancestors did.

column1: 5006482~Grilled Shrimp with Fiery Lemongrass-Chile Sambal~3143~107~38~295~164~6298~2642~To read of my travels
column2: you might get the impression that for most of the last three years
column3: I've done nothing but prowl night markets and food stalls. True
column4: a lot of great grilling takes place on Third World street corners
column5: but you can also find some pretty amazing barbecue at luxury resorts. One such place is Amandari
column6: a hotel built right into a rice paddy near the artist town of Ubud
column7: Bali. Dinner began with a Balinese welcome dance performed by local children in gold-embroidered gowns. My wife
column8: Barbara
column9: and I dined at a table for two strewn with rose petals in an open pavilion facing a lily pond. A team of chefs cooked for us and us alone on portable grills over charcoal. The succession of dishes—grilled shrimp with fiery lemongrass sambal
column10: Balinese grilled chicken
column11: and whole grilled fish with kaffir lime leaves—revealed Balinese cooking in all its polymorphic glory. A profoundly complex cuisine only hinted at in the food at your typical street-corner stall.

Elizabeth told me she made her cakes in glass canning jars and would tuck one into her husband's business trip luggage so he wouldn't miss his favorite cake while he was out of town. column1: 5007139~Guinness-Brined BBQ Lamb Steaks~5274~529~441~294~234~18712~1103~Guinness
column2: the Irish stout
column3: gives the brine for these simple barbecued lamb steaks much of its punch. Like most dark beers
column4: Guinness has a bittersweet molasses flavor
column5: which is great with lamb. But the hidden power of a Guinness brine is its alcohol content (about 4 percent). Alcohol accelerates the absorption of flavorful components directly into the protein structure of meat
column6: yielding a steak that not only retains about 10 percent more moisture
column7: but also is able to deliver a hit of seasoning with every bite. The flavors of chipotle chiles and cumin in the brine are reinforced with a smoky rub and a dark
column8: pungent Guinness BBQ sauce. A word of warning: the sauce burns easily
column9: so only brush it on the meat at the very end of grilling. In fact it is more flavorful served as a table sauce
column10: although the steaks do look nice varnished with glaze.

column6: sold in thick slabs all year long. It is glorious: sticky and rich
column7: winey with rum and almond paste

column1: I tried many times to re-create their Kranz (which means “wreath”) at home and never quite got it right
column2: but in the process I developed this recipe

column5: when the Kranzkuchen is golden brown and shiny from the apricot glaze and topped with a drizzled glaze
column6: it’s as beautiful as it is delicious. I suggest you bake this when you have a lot of people to feed at once—it’s best the day it is made."

column2: Pork
column3: and Lamb~9767~1629~439~347~182~45652~643~"This is the stew that made such an impression on the final episode of the first season of Top Chef Masters. Each of us had been asked to create a meal that would be an autobiography told through the dishes we would present to the judges. I immediately thought of baeckeoffe (""baker's oven""). The name refers back to the time when bakers used wood-fired ovens. After the bread was done
column4: this dish would be baked long and slow in the falling temperatures of the cooling oven. Since everyone in town would see the baker every day for the family's daily loaf
column5: each would often bring a casserole to be baked in the oven. It was traditional
column6: particularly on Mondays
column7: when the women went to the river to do their laundry. They would have marinated their meats and vegetables overnight
column8: dropped their casseroles off in the morning on their way
column9: and then picked them upplus a loaf of breadon their way home. Even though my father was not the bread baker and had a modern
column10: gasfired oven
column11: people still took their casseroles to him. They liked to drop in because he always had some joke or story to tell. Before the village baker also invested in a modern oven and was still using wood
column12: when my father turned over a fresh loaf of bread to give it the traditional blessing
column13: he would sometimes see pieces of charcoal embedded in the crust. That would send my dad wild
column14: muttering that ""he [the baker] did not thoroughly clean his oven!"""

5010072~Nancy's Falafel Pistachios~4320~43~0~1~441~5879~0~Before I left for my trip to Israel with Steven
column2: I had a meeting with the California Pistachio Board. They were planning a lunch at my restaurant Chi Spacca to showcase recipes I was developing that highlighted pistachios. I told them I would soon be on my way to Israel and would return with at least one Israeli recipe to add to the mix because I knew that the pistachio was the peanut of not only Israel but the entire Middle East. Indeed
column3: pistachios were sold at nearly every market I visited in Israel and were widely deployed—and enjoyed—in many dishes. This particular recipe was inspired by the falafel I ate at the wonderful Arab market in Akko. It was so striking that after asking the falafel man what spices were involved
column4: I went to the spice guy at the same market and requested that he recreate the blend. I was a bit concerned that he would not be able to duplicate the mix. But it turned out that my request was not unique. He quickly began grinding away as if he had done this a thousand times. My request was merely the one thousand first.

5011797~Red Velvet Cupcakes with Mascarpone Cream Cheese Icing~12350~1479~935~237~590~5872~1854~Although legend has it that the red velvet cake originated in the early 1900s at New York City's Waldorf Astoria Hotel

column5: which featured a red velvet armadillo groom's cake
column6: a popular Southern tradition that continues to this day. The inspiration for my red velvet cupcakes came from my high-school boyfriend's grandmother. My mother was quite ill during those years
column7: so I spent a lot of time with Bob Yarborough's family. His Birmingham
column8: Alabama–born grandmother cooked and baked frequently
column9: and I never forgot her red velvet cake. I wrote the instructions in my high-school recipe notebook and used it as a guide for developing these cupcakes. The mint extract and crushed mint candies add bit of holiday flair
column10: but easily can be left out at other times of the year.

column1: 5012495~Toasted Manioc Flour With Eggs and Scallions (Farofa de Ovo e Cebolinha)~709~17~5~17~63~375~443~Farofa is the term for a side dish using toasted farinha de mandioca—in English
column2: manioc flour
column3: which is a dried flour similar in looks and texture to breadcrumbs
column4: made from yucca. The making of farofa as a dish couldn't be easier. It is plain manioc flour toasted in butter. A few of the classic farofa dishes include eggs and scallions
column5: eggs and bacon
column6: banana
column7: bell peppers
column8: and dendê oil
column9: green beans and carrots
column10: peas and corn
column11: and so on and so forth. Farofa can be extremely dry
column12: since the manioc flour immediately sucks up all the juices from anything it encounters
column13: especially when it's served plain. The trick to making a moist farofa is to use a small amount of manioc flour in proportion to the other components
column14: turning a side dish into a savory accompaniment that is so tempting

column1: 5015741~Beer-Marinated Flank Steak with Aji and Guacamole~607~67~21~37~61~1593~45~Colombia may be the best kept barbecue secret in South America. Sure
column2: Argentina gets the attention for its cowboy-style asado. And Brazil has enjoyed spectacular success exporting its rodizio-style restaurants—the kind where the waiters parade spits of grilled meats through the dining room. But Colombia? I doubt that most North Americans could name a single Colombian grilled dish. Well
column3: it's time to shine the spotlight on the only country in South America to have coasts on both the Atlantic and the Pacific
column4: whose cool-weather ranching district produces well-marbled
column5: full-flavored beef
column6: whose grill masters make extensive use of marinades (unlike the simplicity prized by their Argentine counterparts)
column7: and whose mastery of the art of grilling on charcoal extends to some unique techniques. Here's a not-so simple flank steak redolent of cumin
column8: green onions

column1: 5012504~Middle Eastern Nut-Filled Multilayered Pastry (Baklava)~5306~613~298~147~257~2871~0~"Baklava (from the Farsi for ""many leaves"")
column2: a pastry perfected by royal bakers in the sultan's palace in Istanbul
column3: consists of layers of phyllo filled with nuts and spices and drenched in a syrup. It has become a traditional Middle Eastern Rosh Hashannah and Purim treat but is enjoyed at celebrations throughout the year. There are numerous variations of baklava
column4: many a closely guarded secret passed down within families. A walnut filling is more prevalent in the Levant
column5: while pistachios and pistachio-almond fillings are preferred in Iran. Blanched almonds are traditional on Rosh Hashannah to produce a light color so that the year should be dulce y aclarada (""sweet and bright""). Sephardim refrain from serving dark-colored pastries such as those made from walnuts on Rosh Hashannah
column6: which would portend a dark year. Although purists disdain anything except the classic nut filling
column7: some cooks innovated by adding such items as dates and chocolate chips. Hungarians make an apricot version. This very rich treat is usually served in small portions."

5013372~Maine Lobster Bake~12955~214~82~638~1032~22418~4462~Of all the great American cookouts
column2: surely the lobster bake
column3: known outside of Maine as the clambake
column4: is the most dramatic. The technique
column5: learned from the original Americans
column6: uses a steaming pit either dug in the sand or made from natural rock formations to cook a wide variety of ingredients without relying on forged pots and pans. The presentation
column7: the most spectacular I have ever seen
column8: is a ten-foot-tall burst of steam released upon removal of the tarp. As the steam subsides
column9: bright red lobsters facing back to back on dark green rockweed come into view. Sweet corn surrounds the lobsters. Underneath the seaweed lie buried treasures: soft-shell clams
column10: rock crabs
column11: a whole fish
column12: mussels
column13: periwinkles
column14: potatoes
column15: boiling onions
column16: sausage and hen or duck eggs. The sights and smells are intoxicating. The lobster bake
column17: much more than a dish or even a feast
column18: embodies a day filled with the wonders of water

5013403~Ginger and Honey Baby Back Ribs~492~111~36~4~0~21949~0~Ribs are among the constants on the world's barbecue trail
column2: but just how theyre prepared reflects a strong regional and cultural bias. The vast ranch lands and forests of the New World
column3: for example
column4: led to American-style barbecue
column5: with its large slabs of spareribs slow-roasted on a smoker for the better part of a day. Asians adopted a different strategy: cooking small cuts or single ribs on tiny grills engineered for fuel efficiency. The flavor would come not from wood smoke (Asians don't have wood to burn by the cord)
column6: but from the explosively flavored seasoning indigenous to the region
column7: like lemongrass
column8: ginger
column9: and fish sauce. Case in point: These Cambodian-style ribs
column10: from Sarun Pich

column12: Cambodia.

column1: 5013591~Pot Stickers~2172~60~21~83~176~3377~215~"These small dumplings come with both a story and a significant history. According to legend

column4: so I first made a melon emulsion. Then I tossed the crabmeat with my Colvin Vinaigrette (which is basically good on anything). I thought that avocado would be great with the melon

column6: then I layered sliced ripe avocado and the crab mixture with a huge quenelle of caviar I had on hand to top it all off. Honestly

column9: ""What the hell is this flavor combination? This is amazing!"" Give it a try—it's elegant and just incredibly good."

column1: 5015392~California Barley Bowl with Lemony Yogurt Sauce~562~23~4~14~47~1146~0~If you grew up in Northern California in the 1990s

column1: 5016672~Baby Tomato and Fresh Goat Cheese Salad~1856~216~54~93~64~3559~171~"This is an early signature dish of my colleague Jonathan Waxman
column2: who has been at the center of the contemporary American food scene since the early 1970s
column3: when he worked at Chez Panisse in Berkeley and at Michael's in Los Angeles. Waxman now presides over Barbuto—he's ""the bearded one""—in the far west Greenwich Village
column4: where all- American inclinations meet simple Italian cooking
column5: frequently in the wood- burning oven. Jonathan's cooking has always been defined by its clarity; there are times when I wonder how he has managed to make something as simple as a roasted chicken or a plate of beets seem so special. Top-quality ingredients in season and vigilant preparations are the answers—what I strive for in my own cooking. This dish is a classic example of the early wave of what was known as the New American Cooking—a movement
column6: if not a revolution
column7: now forty years old and counting. It also demonstrates that a new
column8: even trendy
column9: dish can endure and become a classic—if it has integrity. Nevertheless
column10: you can improvise here. Change the herbs according to what you've got
column11: and the oils for the dressing."

5019572~Turkey Shawarma with Tomato Relish and Tahini Sauce~2573~65~7~273~126~5383~658~Shawarma is the Middle Eastern version of a large vertical shish kebab known as doner kebab in Turkey and gyro in Greece. It's made by impaling layers of meat on an oversize spit with a flat base and roasting the meat in an upright rotisserie. There are at least three advantages to this singular method of cooking. The dripping fat bastes the meat below it; the meat is sliced to order (at least it should be) from the outside
column2: which gives every customer a crusty end cut; and because the crusty meat slices are piled on pita bread with fresh vegetables
column3: pickles
column4: and tahini sauce
column5: you get a whole meal—and a healthful one—in a single sandwich. Traditionally
column6: shawarma was made with lamb
column7: but more and more Israeli grill masters use thinly sliced chicken or turkey. Shawarma is easy to prepare if you have a vertical rotisserie
column8: and somewhat more challenging to adapt to the home grill. But direct-grilling the turkey slices does give you a close approximation of the taste and texture of classic shawarma.

column4: dhal
